title: co-op-announces-prestonpans-store-is-to-close
story: The firm employs  people at the supermarket at Links Shopping Centre on High Street.The news has been met with dismay in the community.Ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell said: ldquoI was sorry to hear about the closure of the Co-op in Prestonpans.ldquoIts late opening hours save local people having to travel out of town.ldquoIt also plays an important role in bringing people onto High Street and helping sustain other businesses.ldquoIt will be a worrying time for the employees, and it is important they are given full support to find other employment.Ms OrsquoDonnell added that she would like to see more investment in Prestonpans to help nurture local businesses and create employment.Fellow ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said: ldquoThis isnrsquot welcome news.ldquoObviously, we want that space open and operating so that it gives facilities for locals to use and also provides much-needed employment.The councillor said that he would be contacting the owners of the site to find out who the next tenant would be.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, added: ldquoWhilst it is very disappointing that the Co-op are closing their store at Preston Links, it strengthens Prestonpans Community Councilrsquos case for a fundamental review of our High Street.ldquoPrestonpans is one of East Lothianrsquos largest towns and deserves a High Street that can attract local shoppers and serve visitors along the John Muir Way.A spokesperson for Co-op said: ldquoThe Co-op is moving forward with real purpose and momentum, and while this usually involves the opening of new stores, we also have to make dficult decisions.ldquoAfter careful consideration, our store on High Street in Prestonpans will close. The last day of trading is expected to be in November.ldquoThis is no way a reflection of the hard work of colleagues, who have been informed, and every effort will be made to find alternative roles for them.ldquoWe would like to thank the community for its support over the years.

title: jaimes-brave-abseil-in-tribute-to-her-dad
story: Jaime Sutherland, of Rowanhill Close, Port Seton, is taking on the abseil in June in aid of Chest, Heart and Stroke Scotland ndash and in tribute to her dad Dave, a civilian police worker, who suffered a fatal heart attack when he was just  years old.Jaime told the Courier: ldquoI saw an advert for abseiling down the bridge on Facebook.ldquoIrsquod already been thinking about doing something to raise money for charity and this seemed the perfect thing.ldquoMy dad passed away in  and I wanted to do something in his memory.ldquoIrsquom not usually a daredevil, but Irsquom not too bad with heights.Jaime has already raised pound through her Everyday Hero page on Facebook.She added: ldquoAll my mates think that Irsquom a bit mad and I think my mum was shocked when I told her what I wanted to do. Irsquom excited, though.As well as studying for her Highers, the -year-old coaches youngsters at Tranent Amateur Swimming Club, as well as working for Splash Start, and she is a leguard at Seton Sands Holiday Park. She was also named Junior Volunteer of the Year at the Tranent and District Community Sport Club Awards in .Mum Lynn added: ldquoIrsquom extremely proud of her.ldquoI know that she suffered anxiety after her dad died, it was a dficult time, so to see her reach this point is amazing.ldquoShersquos always wanted to help other people and has shown maturity beyond her years.ldquoShe is extremely hard-working and a great example at age  to younger people.Jaimersquos younger brother Andrew, , is also extremely supportive of his sister, making a donation to her page with his own money, writing: ldquoSo proud of you sissy, good luck.The family are also organising a disco on June  to help raise extra money for the cause.Anyone wanting to help with raffle donations should email lynncsutherland@aolTo support Jaimersquos abseil, which takes place on June , visit here.

title: lothian-buses-drivers-balloted-over-possible-strike
story: Unite the union confirmed that it will formally ballot its membership at Lothian Buses for industrial action following overwhelming support in a consultative ballot.In a three-week-long ballot,  per cent of Unite members who voted indicated support to take industrial action.Lothian Buses, which has a number of services in East Lothian, has refuted ldquoany allegations of bullying.The move ndash which has no impact on East Coast Buses, which is a subsidiary company of Lothian Buses ndash follows a breakdown in negotiations with Lothian Buses management at the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service .Lyn Turner, Unite regional industrial officer, said: ldquoUnite met with Lothian Buses management at ACAS and we entered those talks in good faith to find a resolution to this dispute.ldquoHowever, there was a refusal at the outset to reinstate facility time, which is a red line for us.ldquoWe have a number of outstanding issues in relation to procedural agreements, which includes on bullying and harassment.ldquoThis is illustrated by the decision to remove facility time for the two senior Unite representatives.ldquoThis decision in our view is trade union victimisation and we will now move to an employment tribunal.A spokeswoman for Lothian Buses said: ldquoDespite the fact that the union and the business attended talks with ACAS last week, Unite thus far seem unwilling to engage in serious discussion.ldquoWe absolutely refute any allegations of bullying.ldquoThe branch chair and secretary are allocated four days per month to attend to their union duties ndash time which is paid for by Lothian and is way above what we are required to provide by law.ldquoWe are at a loss to understand why the union hierarchy is intent on pursuing this damaging course of action that has the potential to impact on our customers.

title: bid-to-buy-site-for-multi-generational-hub-at-north-berwick-turned-down
story: North Berwick Community Development Company, which has more than , members, wants to buy a .-hectare site off the townrsquos Lime Grove.The site, which was previously home to a council depot, is owned by the local authority.A sub-group of North Berwick Coastal Area Partnershipwas formed three years ago with a view to carrying out a community asset transfer.Last Friday, their bid was turned down by the council, which felt there was ldquoinsufficient evidence that the move would ldquopromote or improve economic development, regeneration, public health, social wellbeing or environmental wellbeing.A five-page document posed questions about the projectrsquos funding, adding: ldquoThere are signicant costs attributable to the proposal .ldquoWhilst the business plan is well-structured, East Lothian Council are of the view that there is insufficient evidence that the signicant initial, short-term and long-term funding sources can be properly secured to deliver the proposal.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThe asset transfer request was considered under the agreed process for community asset transfers.ldquoUnder the terms of the Community EmpowermentAct, it was considered that there was insufficient evidence presented that this request would result in community improvements as suggested, nor did the evidence provided concerning possible funding sources for the project.Full details of the decision have been provided to North Berwick Development Company, who have the right to apply to the council to review the decision.Last month, Lime Grove Asset Transfer Group, the NBCAP sub-group, unanimously agreed to appeal the decisionthe request was refused. The group was due to meet yesterday , with a view to deciding the next step.Members are also seeking advice from the Community Ownership Support Service, a Scottish Government-funded programme set up to help groups take on land or building assets for their community.Lesley Kay, chairwoman of Lime Grove Asset Transfer Group and a director of North Berwick Community Development Company, said: ldquoWe are obviously disappointed by this decision.ldquoA great deal of work and community engagement was done to prepare for the community asset transfer request. We will continue with our mission to create a space where people can come together to meet their needs and aspirations.The group wants the site, which has lain vacant for more than five years, transformed into a community hub which could host a youth space, a multi-purpose room for theatre and cinema, a cafe, a soft play area and a hostel. Judy Lockhart, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, said they would discuss the matter at their next meeting.Ward councillor Jeremy Findlay was hopeful the group would try again to satisfy the criteria of the council. He said: ldquoI think the basic concept is good. I just donrsquot think the long-term planning was sufficiently robust.

title: tranent-boxing-gym-owners-bid-to-raise-10000-for-family-of-bradley-welsh

title: six-things-to-do-in-east-lothian-this-easter-weekend
story: Butyoure stuck for what to do with the family, heres a few ideas of things going on around the county this weekend:. title: young-girl-stuck-in-sinking-sands-at-aberlady-bay
story: Leanne Cochrane and her husband Thomas were walking on Aberlady Bay at low tide when their daughter got "pulled in by sinking sands".The family wanted to see the wrecks of the two midget submarines which are buried in the sand and, although quite far out from the coast road, can be viewed at low tide.Leanne said on Facebook that they were on theirjourney on the vast sands when the "horric experience" occurred.Her daughter was, she said, ldquoknees deep" in wet sand when her husband "tried to get her out"."He got pulled in as well but thank God they both got out," she said. "There are no warning signs out there.The response across the social media site was immediate with one person writing: ldquoGlad you are all fine - hope everyone shares this. It must have been terrying.With another saying: ldquoAberlady Bay is dangerous: the sand banks constantly move and the mud sucks you under. Not advisable to walk on it in the winter spring time.Someone  added: ldquoAn easy mistake for anyone to make I agree an information board would be good.Scott Ironside, the countryside ranger at nearby Seton Sands Holiday Park, told the Courier that the most important rule in such situations was not to panic."The more you move your legs, the more you get sucked in," he said." Keep arms up and outward. Remove backpacks etc. Spread body weight evenly and lie on your chest and raise your legs slowly up to ground level then crawl out. If a person nearby has a rope or a branch, thatrsquos better. There is a Bear Grylls video about this on YouTube which has good advice, especially for those who are stuck alone.The midget submarines at Aberlady Bay are XT-Craft, training versions of the X-Craft that attacked the German battleship Tirpitz in .In , two of these vessels were towed to Aberlady Bay and moored to a large concrete block, then used as target practice and gun tests by RAF aircraft.

title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: Marianne Taylor  Time to be more Zenlike when our Scottish banknotes are refused
story: First there was the matter of the pound price tag for two ndash TWO! ndash doughnuts. The tennis coach and mother of Wimbledon champs Andy and Jamie Murray must already have been regretting the decision not to go to Greggs for her sugar fix when she handed over her Bank of Scotland tenner only to be told by the cashier that the shop accepted only ldquoBritish notes.Read more: Judy Murrays Scottish banknote refused in London bakeryAs anyone who has read Ms Murrayrsquos excellent book outlining how she set her sons on the road to sporting greatness through sheer determination will know, Judy is not a woman who takes no for an answer. And, as her quarter of a million Twitter followers will attest, only tennis ranks above her love of cakes. So, although she didnrsquot elaborate on the outcome of the altercation, I can only imagine Ms Murray volleyed back as good as she got and ended up persuading the shop to accept Euros, groats and Monopoly money as well as Scottish cash.The tweet got so much traction because most Scots know and understand exactly how this interaction goes, just how grim and maddening it is no matter how many times yoursquove experienced it. These days many of us feel much more confident in our skins as Scots and are able to consider and reconcile our relationship with our English neighbours in more mature and expansive ways than ever before. But you still canrsquot escape the deep, primeval humiliation of having your money refused. And although this refusing is often down to ignorance rather than malice, especially in London, where so many of those who work in shops, restaurants and cafes are from overseas and donrsquot even know what a Scottish note is ndash why would they  - itrsquos something we Scots just canrsquot seem to get over. I include myself in this. Irsquove lived in London twice and looking back I used Scottish notes to symbolise and conflate the many dferent frustrations I felt with le in the metropolis.Read more: Why Scottish banknotes can be rejectedI could have given Basil Fawlty a run for his money as I ponticated to teenage shop assistants and foreign taxi drivers about ldquolegal tender and ldquoanti-Scottish discrimination, eventually admitting to myself that I found the ranting enjoyable, a form of stress relief, regardless of whether I succeeded in forcing my money upon them or not.Irsquom ashamed to admit now that I used to keep a Scottish tenner specically for the purpose of having a good rammy with the landlord of one of my local pubs. I suspect he enjoyed it just as much as I did, not least because hersquod never miss an opportunity to bring up the old clicheacute about Scots being tight. To give him his due, Irsquod usually get a wink and a free drink, too.The irony of all this, of course, is the fact that the banknotes so many of us defend to the end at cash desks all over England, day in, day out, are not legal tender at all. Not even in Scotland, as it turns out, where only coins have legal weight. According to the Bank of England, both coins and Bank of England notes are legal tender south of the border, with anything  a ldquomatter of agreement between the parties involved. This means each and every one of those painful refusals was legitimate, every ldquoput that in your pipe and smoke it, pal righteous speech made by you was nonsense. I found this out during my second stint in London, changing tack from rants around legality to arguments based on how petty and ldquohurtfultheir actions were. I had more luck with that.Read more: Judy Murrays Scottish banknote refused in London bakeryFormer Lib Dem Scottish Secretary Alistair Carmichael - remember him  - apprently plans to introduce a bill to the House of Commons that would oblige businesses to accept Scottish banknotes as payment. The current incumbent in the job, David Mundell, tried and failed to do something similar in .Other than the fact Parliament probably has more pressing concerns right now, surely this is simply a case of too little too late  With most of us using debit cards and contactless payments these days ndash only three in  transaction now use notes and coins, a figure expected to halve over the next decade - itrsquos clear the days of carrying banknotes of any sort are numbered: the cashless society is within swiping distance. Sweden, the first country to use the banknote back in , is expected to be the first to go completely cashless in .Read more: Why Scottish banknotes can be rejectedMaybe the time has finally come for Scots to stop fighting the good fight  Next time someone refuses your Scottish note, remain Zenlike. ldquoHow could I have been so silly  you will smile as you bring out your contactless card, resisting the urge to scream ldquoitrsquos legal tender, you ignoramus!. Not as much fun, granted, but so much better for the blood pressure.

title: we-can-undo-the-clearances-and-re-people-the-highlands-says-professor-jim-hunter
story: Professor Jim Hunter gazes down Strath Brora at the acres of turf and heather, gorse and bracken. Itrsquos an empty place of rolling hills and crags, wide-open skies, silver water, green turf and lonely beauty. For Hunter, though, the emptiness of the strath, north of the Dornoch Firth in Sutherlandrsquos east, is plain wrong. He points to the fields below us.ldquoYou could live herethere was a house you could afford, next to the loch with a beautul view, he says. ldquoThe Arsquos four miles away, so is the railway ndash this isnrsquot the back of beyond. If effort was put in, it could happen.He points again, to Carrol, a couple of cottages across Loch Brora. In , months after the once-thriving township was cleared and its homes destroyed, the Countess of Sutherland came here, then wrote to her husband, the Marquess of Stafford, of her ldquomelancholy at the sight. The couple would later become the Duke and Duchess of Sutherland, and were the most notorious proponents of the Clearances.ldquoI find it extraordinary, says Hunter. ldquoThe countess writes about it almost asitrsquos an act of God that the place was devastated and in ruins but it was that way because she and her husband had ordered to it to be.Hunterrsquos a historian and a Highlander, and has a deep knowledge of the dark blot on Scotlandrsquos story when much of the population was removed from the land to make way for sheep but for him itrsquos much more than history: the Clearances are something which can at least in part be undone. Land such as this has only been deserted for  years after millennia of occupation, and to him that means it can and should be inhabited again, a process which has become known as ldquore-peopling.He is an influential figure: author of  books on the Highlands and islands, he was the first director of the University of the Highlands and Island Centre for History, and from - was chairman of government development agency Highlands and Islands Enterprise.Now the idea of re-peopling is gaining traction, with substantial Scottish Government backing, and potential changes to planning rules.But can people be brought back to stabilise fragile communities, re-inhabit deserted glens and islands, and bring them to le again As the crow flies itrsquos  miles from Brora to the island of Ulva, off the coast of Mull. What they have in common is near-emptiness, and whatrsquos happening in Ulva is seen as a test case in re-peopling.Rhuri Munro shows me the rented home he shares with his we, Rebecca, and their children Matilda and Ross.ldquoThe walls are starting to crumble, and therersquos constant damp, he says. The leaky roof brought the ceiling down in the childrenrsquos bedroom, and they were moved to the spare room, done up at the familyrsquos expense.They donrsquot need the Raeburnrsquos heat in summer butthey donrsquot run it condensation builds up. Rhuri stabs a finger at a flaking wooden window frame: ldquoTherersquos no insulation. All the windows need replacing. You have to keep pumping your own money in and it got to the stage where we werenrsquot going to do that again.The only other inhabitant of Ulva, pensioner Barry George, lives in a cottage with its own maintenance problems. The Munros say other inhabitants left the island in recent years because of poor rented housing.If the remainder had left it would have completed a process started in . That was when Francis William Clark bought the island. In  years he reduced the population of  to . Roofs were burned to stop families ing Clark carried out evictions in person, acquiring a reputation for callousness.His family sold Ulva in  to the Howards, and it was the Howardsrsquo alleged failure to maintain homes, and lack of security of tenure, that made the Munros back a community buyout when Jamie Howard put it on the market in . For the Munros it was simple: they feared being cleared out by a new owner, like their predecessors. Rebecca says: ldquoWe saw the buyout as our only real option of control.The Duchess, the Highland Clearances, the housekeeper ... and a story to make you weepWhen, after a year of worry for the islanders, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Scottish Land Fundmade a pound.m grant, the buyout could go ahead. On June , , a couple of hundred people gathered on Ulva to celebrate its completion.The grant put the island at the forefront of the re-peopling movement. The SLF, set up to help community buyouts, paid it to the North West Mull Community Woodland Company , the organisation that actually made the purchase.To get the grant it put forward a plan for a major increase in population. As well as proposing to reinhabit existing island houses, the plan says new crofts can be established, and self-builders can have plots, with a long-term target of  people living on the island.One of the people who drew up the plan was community land consultant Calum Macleod, now policy officer for umbrella group Community Land Scotland, and a leading proponent of re-peopling.For him, spending public money to let people live lives many urban dwellers would envy is a matter of maintaining important ersity, vital to stop the inexorable draw of towns and cities.He believes Ulva is a test case: ldquoIt offers an opportunity to show where the potential can be realised for re-peopling and repopulating, he says. ldquoItrsquos not somewhere that is a wild area, there are existing houses, but itrsquos a good example of what can be done.Yorkshireman Ian Hepburn is one of the people charged with re-peopling Ulva. Hersquos a director of NWMCWC, which has forestry land and woodland crofts on Mull, and also chairs CLS. He lives at Dervaig on Mull, eight miles from Ulva.Hepburn meets me at the Ulva jetty a few months after the buyout and we roar off on a quad-bike tour of empty properties the company now owns.Plans to regenerate lost townships decimated by the Highland ClearancesAs well as cottages, there is the big house, with five main bedrooms plus ldquoservantsrsquo quarters. It echoes and the decorrsquos tatty but the property is sound: one idea is to lease it as a small family-run hotel. The old Manse, last lived in eight years ago, is decaying but Ardalum House, used briefly as a tourist hostel, could almost open for business tomorrow.Hepburn says more than  people have expresed interest in living on Ulva. ldquoThe reality and the ambition are not always in line but we will get people for sure wanting to live here when we get houses redeveloped.ldquoThe key thing is they wonrsquot be holiday homes, we want families in them, living and working. With modern telecommunications the location doesnrsquot make much dference to what you do for a living, so wersquore confident we can end up with a ing, living island relatively quickly.Many of the ideas for creating work here are tourism based, but crofts based on the productive land could each provide part of a living.ldquoWe donrsquot want to be modern-day lairds, Hepburn adds. ldquoWe want to create the potential for other people to run a business here to bring the le back.Back in Strath Brora, Jim Hunter points out that re-peopling has happened before, with the creation of crofts by the Government for former soldiers after the First World War, in Skye, the outer isles and where.Hunter says Strath Brorarsquos farmland, neglected for two centuries could be revived, and like Hepburn, believes other work will follow, with internet links a major factor.Pointing to a growing population on Skye, Hunter says when homes are available, people will come and then find or create work.Up the strath at the remains of the former schoolhouse ndash two long, tumbled walls overgrown with bracken ndash Hunter looks south to a wind farm. That kind of development too can provide funds to underpin a community, ldquo it is owned by the community, the money stays here and doesnrsquot go to an outside company.Could more community buyouts, of the Ulva type, foster more re-peopling  The islands of Eigg and Gigha have seen populations grow by % in recent years, as has Knoydart: all three are community owned. On Eigg people who want to live there do find work: some incomers farm but others are journalists, run tourist accommodation, bike hire and craft businesses, recording studios, a brewery...Hunter is a community land enthusiast but he acknowledges a problem with Ulva, Eigg, Gigha and Knoydart as templates for his ideas. ldquoCommunity buyouts can only happen where there is a community, and in places that were comprehensively cleared there are no communities.So, he says, while ownership is an issue, and a change can bring more people in, more fundamental is planning regulations.ldquoOur planning regime tends to the view that a locality such as this in Strath Brora where there is nobody living, should remain one where no-one is living, and houses and businesses are only to be encouraged where there are houses and businesses already.ldquoI can understand that but I think itrsquos not impossible to envisage these things happening in localities where people lived not all that long ago in historical termsldquoIf you look around us here there is no lack of land, there are millions of acres in the Highlands doing not an awful lot, producing not very much. When you think a very small plot where the planners have said you can build a house in many parts of the Highlands now would sell for pound,, there is something completely bizarre about it when there is so much empty land.ldquoIn any real sense that landrsquos real worth should be pound to pound ... We need to revise the planning system and make it easier for people to get house sites.He says to make it easier for people, especially young people, to live in the Highlands the Scottish Government must put together legal and planning frameworks to ensure housing can be built and the system gives priority to social and community need, not private gain.ldquoThe mechanics are not rocket science. Whatrsquos required, but what sometimes seems to be in as short supply as affordable homes, is the political will.That political will is developing: amendments agreed to the Scottish Governmentrsquos proposed Planning Bill by Holyroodrsquos Local Government and Communities Committee include giving Scottish Ministers a duty to take into account the importance of resettling rural Scotland, and of making land available for resettlement. Others, including one to let local councils include re-population as an aim in their planning blueprints, are still on the table.Historian Sir Tom Devine on what really happened during the clearancesWhen I test Hunterrsquos ideas on Brora local history enthusiast Nick Lindsay, another student of the Clearances, he is sceptical about re-population, for Strath Brora at least. He says there are few jobs in the area, adding: ldquoThere would be a huge cost of infrastructure: I donrsquot see where the money would come from. Itrsquos a romantic notion but I think the practicalities are too hard to overcome.Hersquos not the only sceptic: Ulvarsquos Jamie Howard, now a flat-dweller in Edinburgh, says of re-peopling: ldquoIt has become a bit of an obsession with the government and an exercise in flag-waving, with this willingness to wind the clock back to the Clearances. On Ulva, the SNPrsquos ideal would be an island full of people with the right accent, singing from the same hymn sheet.But Sarah Jane Laing, chief executive of landownersrsquo group Scottish Land and Estates, takes a conciliatory tone, saying her members are the biggest housing providers in the countryside and would be happy to see more homes: ldquoWersquove got members all over the Highlands and Islands desperately trying to get planning permission for housing, she says.ldquoThose of us working in land management and land reform are not that far apart ndash what we and Community Land Scotland wants is to have sustainable rural communities.Hunter says resettlement of now-wild areas can go hand-in-hand with better environmental stewardship, pointing to estate records showing wildle was more ied and prolic when Strath Brora was heavily inhabited.Perhaps surprisingly the John Muir Trust wild land charity broadly agrees, even though re-peopling could mean homes on ldquowild land.The Trustrsquos chief executive, Andrew Bachell, says truly remote areas are unlikely to be re-inhabited: ldquoMost of what you would want to do to improve the ecology would involve having people there to manage it, he says. ldquoIf wersquore talking about more people in the north-west Highlands I donrsquot think therersquos any conflict with that and the rewilding agenda, in fact wild land will be one of the reasons people want to live there.While sceptics will always question the level of Government spending on near-empty Ulva when there are other pressing needs, the people at the sharp end donrsquot doubt the dference the re-peopling project will make.Rebecca Munrorsquos battered home on Ulva will be renovated as part of the drive to improve housing stock, and she can invest more in the Boathouse Restaurant next door that she runs with sister-in-law Emma McKie.I catch the strength of emotion in Rebeccarsquos voice when she talks of a future with other children to play with hers in the evening after the ferry has stopped running. Therersquos emotion there too when she speaks of the buyoutrsquos place in history.One of her favourite places on the island is known as Starvation Point, where th-century residents cleared from their old homes and too old or too sick to leave were left to fend for themselves.ldquoItrsquos sad but itrsquos also a really inspirational place, Rebecca says. ldquoA couple of times when things got really dficult with the buyout process I went down there and I thought, lsquothese people didnrsquot have any of these opportunities wersquove had, so just suck it up and get on with it, because you can do something and they couldnrsquot.rsquoldquoItrsquos very dficult not to get upset or angry about at what was done. The villages and townships are still very visible. When the Clearances happened those people had no rights and they had no comeback about what was happening, so there was definitely a bit of righting the wrongs that were done then, in our buyout.Where did the money come from The grant of pound. million by the Scottish Government to buy Ulva was a statement of intent about re-population. But how did it come about, and did connections between Government, grant-givers and the buyout group play a part After Ulva went on the market in , the Government, unusually, put the sale on hold. Then, in October , it allowed North West Mull Community Woodland Companyto register an interest in the estate as a community buyout objective, to allow it a clear run at a deal. This is normally done before any suggestion of a sale.A bid for pound.m went to the Scottish Land Fund , which can give pound million a year of Government cash to community buyouts. Its normal upper limit for single grants is poundm, but the fund backed the bid and referred it to ministers. It was approved in May .The chair of the SLF committee, which decides grants, is John Watt. He emphasises the SLF is run independently of government.ldquoWe had to take quite a few things into consideration, the impact on the budget, the wider land reform policy, as well as the intrinsic merits of the case, he says. ldquoOur decision was that given all the factors and given our understanding of the policy context for Government objectives to ersy the land ownership pattern ... we should recommend that this should be approved.He says the fund was aware a huge grant for Ulva could hit worthy smaller projects, but the government indicated extra money would be availableUlva went ahead.In fact, the Scottish Government says, a poundm underspend on the SLFrsquos budget in - was allowed to be carried over into -, to cover most of the Ulva cash.Meanwhile those involved in the bid say they maintain a professional distance between dferent aspects of their work, and no undue influence was brought to bear on the Scottish Government or the SLF.Calum MacLeod was a member of the Scottish Land Fund committee from its start in  until March . In July  he was engaged as one of three consultants to write the feasibility study submitted to the fund by NWMCWC to support the Ulva bid.Since then he has become part-time policy officer for Community Land Scotland , the prominent umbrella group that makes much of its income from work for the Scottish Government. He previously carried out projects for CLS, Highlands and Islands Enterprise and the Scottish Parliament. He says there is no suggestion his connections helped propel the Ulva grant application.Duncan MacPherson, who has worked extensively with community buyouts and was another of the Ulva consultants, is a member of the SLF committee, and was when the Ulva application was submitted.He declared an interest and took no part in discussions about Ulva, saying: ldquoI went on the committee to make sure people with experience of the sector took part in decisions ... The committee met separately to discuss the Ulva bid and I wasnrsquot even in the building.Ian Hepburn, a director of NWMCWC, also chairs CLS.Hepburn says: ldquoIn terms of did I take an active part in [the SLF grant application] or speak to anyone at the Scottish Government about it, I absolutely did not.

title: black-rooster-per-peri-pollokshaws-road-glasgow-review-by-ron-mackenna
story: GlasgowWErsquoVE only been in the place, say, three minutes and the boom, boom, shouty, shouty music is already doing my head in. Itrsquos so bloody loud. My fingers, which should be in my ears, are actually hovering over the phone to text Garry and tell him: change of plan, mate: letrsquos bolt somewhere .Then I realise he hasnrsquot replied to the last text I sent and will no doubt be bimbling dreamily and unstoppably through the south side at this very moment. I can tell you by the time he arrives it will simply be too late to get up and move on as Irsquoll be trapped by the tractor beam of polite social le.I will also have looked up the internet by then and discovered some curious things. One: the question someone posted on Googleabout whether the chicken in here is organic remains deafeningly unanswered. Be serious: itrsquos  quid for a whole chicken.Two: is this something of a stealth Glesgow-esque phenomenon having branches in Duke Street, in Possil, here on Pollokshaws Road as well as in Paisley and Coatbridge. Pretty much the fast food equivalent of New York, Paris and Rome.Three: someone has claimed this is a cut-price alternative to Nandorsquos Four: they have a website and an app but neither seem to work. In the slightest.Five: None of the other customers, and there are a surprising number on this mid-week evening, seem in the least bit bothered by eating in a disco . And, yes, they are all younger.Anyway, Garry arrives and we sit around in the racket until the penny drops that just like Nandorsquos we have to get up and order at the counter. Drsquouh.Now, this is one of these places where itrsquos actually hard to tell the customers from the staff and I go through the whole ordering process with a cheery guy who nips out from one of the booths and slides behind the counter.I know he does work here because during the actually very entertaining banter back and forward, and while I roll my eyes at being asked yet again what sauce with that, he says, therersquos a sauce with everything in here, mate. And there is Mango  lime, lemon  herb, BBQ, extra mild sauce, extra hot sauce, yadayada.I canrsquot even remember which ones I chose because this place being brand new and having racked up pound. of goodies Irsquom then told itrsquos cash-only and sent off to the nearest corner shop with a cashline machine. Groan. To be fair when Ithey take that p of smash off the bill for my sterling efforts.The food comes to the table real fast. Now, normally at this point and even with the most gallus of places the first mouthful confirms that on the plate anyway dreariness is the order of the day. Hang on. Not so tonight. Crash, bang, wallop goes my palate as first super chilli heat, then salt, then moist chicken with a crispy skin is demolished. There is some sort of lemsippy side flavour too.Joanna Blythman reviews Cannonball in EdinburghBeing a namby pamby restaurant critic I should be completely horried by this assault on the senses, swoon at the crude flavours, and storm off to snort some lavender water. And, actually, the sauce itself oozes and pools in a slightly alarming way, and is a weird colour, but somehow I really like the rude, crude flavours and its very, er, totally Glasgow bravado.Not so impressed with the quesadilla or the toasted paneer wrap. Maybe because they seem to be pretty much exactly the same, being oozy, cheesy, toasty things at a nonetheless inexpensive pound each.The staff are relaxed and friendly, the bants are pretty good and by the time you leave you will definitely know yoursquove eaten something.Black Rooster Per-PeriPollokshaws RoadGlasgow  Menu: Itrsquos a Glasgow or Lanarkshire chicken chain joint with Portugesuey flavours and quesadillas and chips and, well, yoursquove know the script.  Service: Super casual but actually quite good fun and pleasant. Food came super fast too.  Price: Itrsquos very cheap, with those quesadillas and wraps at a mere pound and the menu topping out with a whole saucey chicken at pound. Donrsquot tell Hugh.  Atmosphere: I hated itrsquos non stop super-loud music but then fat old guys are probably not the target audience.  Food: Easy to sneer but the chicken was actually properly cooked, the flavours super-gallus and in your face and I liked them. Yoursquoll know yoursquove eaten.

title: snp-mp-calls-for-a-network-of-tunnels-for-scotlands-islands
story: Now a Western Isles MP has suggested a way to permanently connect Scotlandrsquos islands to the mainland and each other ndash by building tunnels.Angus MacNeil said links under the Sound of Barra, Sound of Kerrera off Oban and between Mull and the mainland would get rid of five ageing CalMac ferries alone.And he insisted a tunnel between the Isle of Harris and Skye was also ldquonot out of the question.The SNP veteran has pointed to the success of the Faroe Islands in creating a transport network which includes  land tunnels and two subsea tunnels ndash with another almost complete and construction on a further tunnel due to start soon.The system, which will include the worldrsquos first subsea roundabout, will virtually eradicate the need for ferry services, he said.Mr MacNeil has now written to Transport Secretary Michael Matheson suggesting the Scottish Government visit the Faroes to learn from its experience and see the new . km subsea tunnel.He said: ldquoThe transport network in the Faroes is the kind of system we should aspire to follow in the Scottish islands.ldquoThe Sound of Barra, Sound of Kerrera and a link from Mull are all prime examples of what could be done and a tunnel from Harris to Skye is also not out of the question.ldquoInfrastructure of this kind would have huge economic and social benefits to all parts of the islands and would remove travel disruption due to weather conditions or issues associated with capacity.Mr MacNeil, who is chair of the Commons International Trade Committee, said the new Faroes tunnel will see travel distances slashed.A drive from the capital of Toacutershavn to the towns of Runaviacutek and Strendur will be reduced from  minutes to just , he said.In order to increase safety, no inclination in the tunnel is steeper than  per cent and the lowest point is  meters below the waterrsquos surface.It comes after Western Isles Council previously put forward ambitious proposals to build a network of bridges and causeways between islands.The plans were among  priority projects listed as part of a proposed ldquoIslands Deal aimed at mirroring similar investment in Scotlandrsquos cities.Suggested schemes included building fixed links over the Sound of Harris and the Sound of Barra, connecting Harris to North Uist and South Uist to Barra.This would allow drivers to travel the full -mile stretch of the island chain for the first time ndash creating one of Scotlandrsquos most spectacular road trips.Tourism chiefs hailed the potential boost to visitor numbers, but experts warned of the large costs associated with such a project.It is understood full details around an Islands Deal will be unveiled later this year.A Western Isles Council spokesman said its long-term aspirations ldquowould include improved fixed links between our Islands including causeways and or tunnels.He added: ldquoHowever these would require major investment and there are many other improvements in the areas of connectivity, housing, tourism, energy infrastructure and transportation that we would wish to see developed more immediately.Officials previously said earlier plans for a -mile tunnel between North Uist and Skye - connecting the Outer Hebrides to the mainland - had ldquodropped out as a priority.Six years ago a sub postmaster in Lochboisdale, South Uist, surprised islanders by placing a fundraising bottle on her counter to raise poundm for a tunnel to Skye.Anne MacLellan initially raised pound, meaning she only had another pound,, to go to realise her dream.The -year-old said at the time: ldquoIf other countries like Sweden, Denmark and the Faroe Islands can have such tunnels and bridges, why canrsquot we ldquoWe need to look forward not backwards, be a progressive country.ldquoThe ferry service here is not meeting our needs - people canrsquot get on them when they want and often they donrsquot run, or there are not enough of them in the summer.ldquoHow much in subsidy does CalMac get over  years  When you add it up a tunnel is not such a daft idea. And it would mean  hour access.

title: what-it-feels-like-to-be-a-tyrannosaurus-rex
story: THE -million-year-old fossilised bones of a Tyrannosaurus rex were excavated in Montana in . Named Trix ndash after the former Dutch queen Beatrix ndash it is among three of the most complete T. rex skeletons to exist anywhere in the world, with between - per cent of its bone volume recovered.There are only about  known specimens in total, so any tyrannosaur material found is pretty exceptional. Some of the earliest ones, for instance, only had a partial jaw. Trix is considered to be female. There is a lump just above the eye socket and it is believed that the larger the lump, the more likely the animal is female.Trix would have eaten other dinosaurs such as Triceratops. T. rex probably didnt run very fast, only about mph because the femur to tibiain the leg are very similar. Fast-running animals tend to have a much shorter femur to tibia ratio. It could have caught some of the smaller dinosaurs that didnt run very fast and would probably have scavenged and eaten dead animals too. The T. rex had a well-developed part of the brain allowing it to smell things precisely.Many early depictions of dinosaurs were as slow and lumbering creatures on four legs. Even the Megalosaurus, a big meat-eating dinosaur, was depicted as a lizard on four legs. Because the tyrannosaurus had such short limbs at the front, there is no way it could have walked about on four legs.Why T. rex had such short arms is one of these things that is unsolved. But it probably did have reasonably bulky muscles on those arms. They werent just passive and useless. They may have been used to rip flesh apart once prey was killed or while scavenging the meat off another animal. T. rex had a huge head full of teeth which were very sharp and serrated which suggests it was a meat-eater. If you compare its bite to a crocodile, it would have had roughly  times the snapping power.There are interesting pathologies about Trix, including some in vivo damage to bones such as fractures that may have occurred as it battled with other T. rex or during mating. There may have been injuries caused during its early development or from a birth defect. If you look closely on the skeleton, there is what could be a small bite to the lower jaw that has healed over. On the ribs there is distorted growth, probably due to a fracture when it was younger.It may be that Scotland is the birthplace of the tyrannosaurs. I found a tailbone of a theropod dinosaur in  and a tooth in  on Skye that may be from primitive tyrannosaurs. That was from the Middle Jurassic period, roughly  million years ago. The early ancestors of tyrannosaurs could have evolved in Scotland. And then evolved much later in the US and Russia as Tyrannosaurus. Trix is from the Cretaceous period, which was around  million years later than the Middle Jurassic.Interview with Dr Neil Clark, curator of palaeontology at The Hunterian in Glasgow University.T. rex in Town is co-organised by Glasgow Museums and The Hunterian. Trix will be on show at Kelvin Hall until July . Visit kelvinhall.org.uk trex

title: the-herald-diary-easter-funnies
story: GREAT weather for the Easter weekend, and it makes us think of previous Easter stories in The Diary, including the Bearsden reader who told us he was spending Easter on Lanzarote when a little boy came running up the beach to tell his sunbathing mother in a distinctly Glasgow accent: "A big wave knocked me over and a wummin had tae help me oot." "What was yer da doin " asked the mum. "Laughin" replied the wee boy.Bet on itHOLIDAYING at Easter was a Glasgow chap who had been persuaded by his family to go pony trekking in the Lake District. Being a tad dubious about the venture, he asked his we as they were putting on their riding helmets, and surveying the four-legged beasts in front of them: "How can I pick the slowest one " "Put a bet on it," his we replied. "That usually works for you.Lets face itA SOUTH side reader once told us she had her two young grandsons staying over at Easter while their parents had a break. She had put the boys to bed, and had gone for a shower when she heard them noisily jumping around the room. With her make-up off, clad in a dressing gown, and her hair bundled into a towel, she stormed into their room and told them to get to sleep. As she left the room she heard one of the boys whisper: "Who was that GulpLETS not forget the actual meaning of Easter, as we recall a primary teacher telling her class the story of the Crucixion. The little ones were enthralled with the story, and you could hear a pin drop in the classroom. She came to the part where Jesus on the cross was thirsty, and she continued: "And guess what they gave him to drink  Vinegar!" The classs silence was broken by one youngster declaring: "The b*******!". "Quite so," declared Miss, and carried hurriedly on.Just the ticketNOW just because its Easter it doesnt mean all the parking meters in Glasgow are free to use. We remember a reader going back to his car on an Easter Monday which was being ticketed, and he remonstrated with the warden that it was a bank holiday. "Its no a bank holiday for me, pal," he replied, and kept on writing.Egged onGROWING old continued. An Anniesland reader once told us: "Now at an age where my we and I have our own Easter hunt ndash I hunt for her glasses and she looks for my car keys.Flight of fancyTHE airports can be busy at this time of year and one reader recalled: "When my granddaughter was four, we went as a family group to Florida at Easter. At Glasgow Airport, we went through all the queues, check in, passport control, body scan, etc, which took over an hour. When we finally emerged into the departure lounge, my granddaughter asked, Are we in Florida now rsquo"FlushedTHERE will be a few folk out messing on boats this weekend. One Easter a reader told us: "My brother was getting his boat out of the water at Rhu Marina for the hull to be cleaned and painted. It was the first time he had done this, and as he inspected the hull he found a hole in the underside which concerned him. He poked his finger in and waggled it about while asking the marina guys, Is this serious  The marina guy asked, Has your boat got a toilet  I have never seen a digit extracted so quickly.Write onAND, finally, there was the primary school pupil who asked her dad at Easter: Daddy, how do you make love  Recalled her Dad: Heart pounding, I had the presence of mind to ask why she wanted to know. Well, she said, I know it begins with L. She was writing an Easter card to us.

title: kevin-mckenna-this-easter-the-church-must-re-discover-its-soul-and-forsake-greed-and-materialism
story: In these dark hours it might even have seemed that secular France, once considered the diadem in the crown of medieval popes, had ed to the old faith and that the Notre Dame fire had been the act of a sorrowful God intended to remind his children of His presence and His power. To most others it was a modern tragedy born of mere happenstance. And to grateful newspaper editors it was a gorgeous picture that would carry a poster front page beneath a ser font and look magnicent the next day on a thousand news stands.More than one billion euros have been pledged to the cost of rebuilding this stricken icon of France. Among the offers of help came one from the custodians of Glasgow School of Art which has encountered its own trials by fire. Presumably, this kind gesture did not include advice on how to fit a sprinkler system.Some of the quantums were eye-watering and included  million euros from the LrsquoOreal cosmetics house as well as donations from Nissan and Prince Albert of Monaco. The worldrsquos most anointed people were rising, almost as a single organism, to come to the aid of Notre Dame, this ancient icon of timeless beauty and an emblem of all that they have tried to capture in their global brands.It would be churlish and cynical to talk of tax-breaks and virtue-signalling here but the decision to spend a few hundred million euros for the privilege of being forever associated with the repair of such a grand place will not have encountered much resistance from their marketing directors. If you required proof of how quickly very rich people can be parted with their money for the right kind of cause then you had it right here. That re-roofing a church administered by the Catholic Church, one of the richest organisations on Godrsquos earth is the lsquorightrsquo type of cause remains open to debate.The Catholic Church has lost so many of its adherents over the last few decades that it now finds itself the custodian of some highly desirable, but very empty real estate throughout western Europe. In my own neighbourhood, just north of Glasgow, a single priest administers three dferent parishes, each with a house that ranks among the grandest in the vicinity. There are thousands of these barren properties across the continent, desolate tokens of lost power and authority. If sold on the open market they would raise a sum not far away from that required to undertake the task of repairing the roof of Notre Dame .The residence of the archbishop of Edinburgh in Morningside sits amidst properties owned by JK Rowling and the most affluent scions of the capitalrsquos establishment. I visited it once and couldnrsquot tell you what purpose it serves beyond maintaining a pastor of a church that purports to represent the poor in the style of a prince. You may even wonderthe great whited sepulchre of the Vatican was what our saviour had in mind for the successors of Peter.Pope Francis has urged his clergy to adopt a much more austere and frugal lestyle as befits the successors of Jesus, a man born into poverty and persecution and who died unjustly, a wretched and forsaken man. In Scotland, as in other countries across Europe, the message of Pope Francis appears to have fallen on stony ground when you observe the splendour in which some of these princes of Rome reside. In the wake of the decades-long evil of clerical sex abuse and the iniquitous cover-ups that followed the pews have emptied but you couldnrsquot mark some of the necks of those who acquiesced in this with a blow-torch. Thus, appeals for them to live a more stripped-down existence and one closer to their flock are hardly likely to ruffle the folds of their gold-stitched vestments.In the empty space once occupied by the roof of Notre Dame and in its charred remains below itrsquos possible to see a metaphor for all thatrsquos befallen the Catholic Church. It has caved in on itself, brought down by the weight of its own arrogance and corruption. It needs reformed and re-constructed but not in the way that Notre Dame will be re-built to restore power and glory. Its renewal must result in a simpler, more humble church: one that will welcome the poor and the outcasts embrace sinners and not judge them. Those who will use it to denounce and to seek power and money should find this place to be a hostile environment.When Easter Sunday dawns tomorrow the faithful will proclaim that Christ is risen and that he is a real presence in the world today. We will also remember the  million Christians around the globe who, according to the Dutch charity Open Doors, are persecuted, suffer and die for their faith. This is a Church whose central message has prevailed over , years and which continues to be a force for great good in the world. Its humanitarian work in those places where governments fear to tread or consider beneath their concern is incalculable. It will always be hated and held to be contemptible by the ignorant the conceited and the materialistic. Its tragedy is that it has come to embrace these vices rather than abjuring them.It must re-discover unconditional love, humility and charity, those virtues that changed lives and improved nations. The world has never needed it more to be like this to resemble more closely the le of the messiah. This cannot happen though, until its priests and ministers take a long overdue vow of poverty, humility and obedience to the simple truth of the Gospel of Jesus.

title: transformed-wallace-monument-gives-new-perspective-on-scottish-hero
story: In September , the forces of Andrew Moray and Wallace defeated the combined English armies of John de Warenne, the th Earl of Surrey, and Hugh de Cressingham, near Stirling on the River monumentrsquos three galleries includes the Hall of Arms, which now houses Wallacersquos medieval sword.Hundreds of visitors to the upgraded landmark on the Abbey Craig at Stirling can also founder of the Maggiersquos cancer centres, Maggie Keswick Jencks, have also been installed in the attractionrsquos ldquoHall of Heroes.The two women were selected to be cast in stone following a public vote in  and are the first in the gallery depicting female figures.For over a century, the gallery has hosted only the busts of great Scotsmen including Robert the Bruce and the poet Robert Burns.The transformation has been managed by Stirling District Tourism , the charity that operates the historic attraction, and a team of specialist contractors led by Edinburgh-based designers Studioarc.Zillah Jamieson, SDT chair said: ldquoIn the monumentrsquos th anniversary year, we wanted to tell the story of William Wallace better than it has ever been told in the past.ldquoThe upgraded exhibition spaces will resonate with modern audiences from all over the world, through dynamic storytelling and digital enhancements.Lauren Drill, , a teacher from Philadelphia touring We were really excited to learn about William Wallace and see where the real le events actually happened.Lyndsey Bowditch, a director of exhibition designers StudioArc, said: ldquoWallace has been revered as a Scottish hero for  years.ldquoAt the heart of Wallacersquos story is his success defeating the English army against all the odds at the Battle of Stirling Bridge.The ft Gothic tower first opened to the public in  as a tribute to the th century hero.

title: members-wont-mention-theresa-may-on-doorsteps-as-tories-prepares-for-election-drubbing
story: The Prime Minister has become synonymous with ldquobetrayal over Brexit in votersrsquo minds, leading some activists to try to focus on local issues, rather the Governmentrsquos main goal.Tory extension of Brexit until October  also means the UK must take part in EU elections on May , unless MPs can agree a Brexit deal by then.With no sign of a breakthrough in talks between the Government isive.Mrs Mayrsquos unpopularity threatens to disrupt Ruth Davidsonrsquos imminentto frontline politics after a six-month maternity break.The Scottish Tory leader backed Mrs May for the Tory title: scottish-pensioners-spray-city-centre-wall-with-graffiti-artwork
story: The  senior citizen spent three days in the classroom learning about graffiti as part of the Nuart Aberdeen festival.After designing their own tags, the pensioners sprayed a mural on a wall in the city centre of the Granite City.It is the first time the Lata- Young At Art project, which teaches graffiti to older people, has taken place in the UK.Retired teddy-bear maker Pearl Cameron, , was proudly spraying her tag of two hearts on the wall.ldquoThis is probably one of the most exciting things Irsquove done, Mrs Cameron said.ldquoTherersquos no age in street art. It breaks down barriers and walls.ldquoOlder people would just love to do things that the young people are doing and this is a wonderful opportunity to do it.Mrs Cameron said the group, most of whom had only met on the first day of the workshop, had been taken through the ldquowhole process of street art.They spent days carefully designing at least three stencils, forming their inidual graffiti tags.ldquoMy tag is two hearts because I am a heart recipient, Mrs Cameron said.ldquoI had a heart transplant  years ago. One of the hearts is my new heart, with the other my broken one.Maggie Wilcockson, , a retired registered nurse and midwe, signed up to the workshop to make new friends.ldquoThere are so many dferent things that your tag can be, she said.ldquoIrsquove lived overseas a lot so Irsquove represented that through the blue, purple and green colours of spray paint.Lata-, which means Over  in Portuguese, and the people asking the interesting questions were the seniors, she said.ldquoWe started teaching this and we noticed that people were coming in with low self-esteem but they left smiling, with high ndash  April Awesome preview from @FthWallTV #nuartaberdeen #nuart #aberdeen@AbdnInspired @AberdeenCC @BurnessPaullLLP @McgintysGroup @CANOffshore @arrestedmotion @JuxtapozMag @GraffitiArtMag pic title: pope-francis-laments-all-the-crosses-of-the-world
story: He included those borne by migrants who find doors closed due to ldquopolitical calculations and children who are harmed in their ldquoinnocence and purity, in a reference to paedophiles in the clergy.From a canopied  on the Palatine Hill, Francis watched the traditional Via Crucistorchlit night-time procession at the Colosseum in Rome, which solemnly recalls the crucixion of Jesus.Along with thousands of pilgrims, tourists and Romans, he listened to reflections that were composed by an elderly Italian nun, who for  years has gone out to the cityrsquos streets to bring comfort and hope to migrant women who were trafficked into prostitution.Francis prayed to Jesus to help ldquous to see in your cross all the crosses of the world.The pope cited persons starved for food and for love, and those ldquoabandoned even by their own children or parents.Then he touched on two issues heavily marking his papacy ndash how to promote the cause of often rejected migrants and to deal with a sea of scandals over Catholic clergyrsquos sexual abuse of children.Francis said migrants ldquofind doors closed because of fear and hearts hardened by political calculations.He also decried the ldquocross of the little ones, wounded in their innocence and their purity. Francis did not directly cite the church scandals.The nun, Eugenia Bonetti, who works with many Nigerian women and other migrants who have fallen prey to human traffickers, spoke with Francis just before the start of the procession.She told Rai state TV that ldquowe are all responsible for these womenrsquos plight, saying ldquoindference is the biggest reason these girls are still on the street.In one of her meditations, read aloud as the faithful listened in utter silence, she said ldquoit is easy to wear a crucix on a chain around our neck or to use it to decorate the walls of our beautul cathedrals or homes.Less easy is acknowledging ldquotodayrsquos newly crucied, the homeless, unemployed youth, ldquoimmigrants relegated to slums at the fringe of our societies after having endured untold suffering, the nun said.Populist leaders in Italy and several other European countries have taken to holding a hard line against migrants, refusing to accept those rescued at sea from traffickersrsquo unseaworthy boats.The US administration of Donald Trump is also determined to keep out illegal migrants.Among those taking turns at carrying a lightweight cross in the procession were a Nigerian woman and her daughter.In his brief comments, expressed in the form of a prayer, Francis also spoke of the ldquocross of the church, which he said ldquofeels continuously under assault from the inside and the outside.The pontf did not elaborate but staunchly conservative and more liberal factions among church hierarchy have been bitterly at odds during his six-year-old papacy.Eroding the churchrsquos moral credibility has been a flood of criticism from faithful and civil authorities in several countries over prelatesrsquo systematic shuffling of paedophile priests from parish to parish for decades rather than remove them from access to children.Earlier, during an evening prayer service, in St Peterrsquos Basilica, Francis kissed a crucix held up in the centre aisle, then pressed his forehead for a moment against the wooden statue depicting Jesus.In another moment, he prostrated himself on the basilica floor in a sign of humility.

title: rab-mcneils-week-watch-out-bozzie-bear-is-about-to-be-let-out-of-his-box
story: Well, itrsquos beginning to look like our prayers might be answered: but only in Scotland. I refer not to the forthcoming European elections, in which the Conservatives will be annihilated UK-wide. No one cares about the European elections. Even ardent Europhiles have never paid much attention to what goes on in the European Union.We elect people under some peculiar system ndash that bizarrely saw Scotland sending a Ukip MEP to Belgium, or wherever it is ndash and then we never hear of them again.No, Irsquom referring to the news this week that support among Tory MPs to have Boris Johnson replace Theresa May as party leader has grown exponentially and hersquos pretty much a shoo-in. Apparently, theyrsquore approaching his office at the rate of five a day to show fealty.One of the reasons for this is easy to understand and one is dficult. The easy one is that, once momentum like this takes hold, these power-hungry boobies will be looking for preferment. The dficult one is that they seem to see a new Boris, a more sensible and presentable Boris, made so by his latest lumber, Carrie Symonds, aged .At the time of going to press, I am far too busy to properly research what she does but a quick look on yon Google suggests it is something to do with elephants. Perhaps this is what attracted her to Boris. However, it turns out that, privately, she refers to him as ldquoBozzie Bear, after televisionrsquos Fozzie, an alleged Muppet.Not only that but she has made him less elephantine, putting him on a diet through which he has lost several tons and, for a while, looked lost in his capacious suits, which have now been replaced by svelte new ones.Hersquos also stopped drinking, which will have his hero Churchill spinning in his grave, but worst of all is what she has done to his hair. Therersquos no other way to describe it than with the horrible insult ldquonormal.Where before his barnet was tousled in a manner that made Worzel Gummidge look tidy, today it is shorter and unremarkable, making him look likewise. Indeed, the whole slim, teetotal, cofured mien has aged him about  years. Already, he looks more careworn than of old, possibly as a result of also affecting greater gravitas. All in all, there is less gaiety about the man and, letrsquos face it,we must have a Boris, then better that it is a buffoon. For that way he will never attain power.While he might be able to win over Tory MPs, winning over the electorate might be an entirely dferent matter. Deep down, the farce remains strong in this reborn Jedi, and ious undignied incidents from the past will be wheeled out by his opponents to remind the electorate of his fundamental nincompoopery.However, England loves a toff, and therersquos no sayinghis new dullness might make him seem fit for office. Scotland, by contrast, hates a toff, and the prospect of Boris actually becoming Prime Minister will see us independent by November at the latest.The prospect is making even the Scottish Conservatives think about rebranding themselves as, er, Scottish, which could make them more electable, in the doubtful eventuality of anyone falling for it.This week, The Independent revealed that Boris had moved into spacious rooms ndash big enough to house a campaign team ndash above the Portcullis House atrium. The office was offered to him by former minister Mike Penning, who said: ldquoHe could well be the next Prime Minister, so it needs to be a credible office at the heart of Westminster ndash not in a box in some annexe hellipNo, the box, keep him in the box! Meanwhile, parents in Scotland so inclined can scare the children with these words: ldquocould well be the next Prime Minister.That will certainly make things interesting for Scotland, England, Europe and the world: the first gone, the second hallucinating, the third tittering and the fourth bewildered.***THERErsquoS nowt as peculiar as folk. This is currently being demonstrated in yonder Russia, where  per cent of the citizenry have expressed approval of Stalin. Only  per cent thought him a bit dodgy.Folk lay flowers on his grave, municipalities are putting up statues to him again, and President Vlad Putin has talked about the ldquoexcessive demonisation of good old Uncle Joe. A contrarian could argue that killing  million people was a tad excessive, but itrsquos all relative, I suppose.Still, it really makes you wonder about memory and the burying of bad history. You have to consider too that the aforementioned  per cent have the vote .Surely, there must be a case for suppressing democracy in Russia, rounding up these people and working them to death in internment camps  Irsquom getting a message on my headphones from my columnar handler saying therersquos a fundamental flaw in my argument.Never mind. I guess what the Russians like is stability, order and a strong leader.Luckily in Britain, we tend to go in more for barely controlled chaos with bumblers at the helm. Long may it continue ndash and it willBoris gets in.***A NEW explanation has been found for Brexit: the decline in communal beer-drinking down the pub.An anthropologist at the University of North Carolina, Americashire, says beer kept ancient civilisations stable and is still a vital ingredient in social cohesion today.Communal boozing, he says, fostered compromise and debate among leaders. I canrsquot pretend thatrsquos been my experience. Folk get more entrenched in their opinions with every pint and tell everybody  to shut up before before the evening ends in the traditional Scottish manner with fists swinging and the sound of sirens getting closer.Beer does bring folk together, right enough, but it tends to be people of like minds in the first place. Itrsquos hard to imagine Brexiteers and Remainers, both of whom should be avoided by decent ratepayers, sitting down to have an amicable pint.When communal quaffing declines, says the academic, ldquolarge political entities begin to fragment. Brexit is an example of this in the European Union today.Brexit is certainly driving many people to drink, though mainly in the privacy of their own homes, where at least you donrsquot have to listen to other peoplersquos opinions and can chunter away unchallenged in righteous fermentation.***DEATH news, and the latest research about the controversial phenomenon suggests we know when wersquore dead and are aware of whatrsquos going on around us: doctors lighting up a fag, family members cheering, bin bag requested and so forth.According to a top boffin in yonder United States, advances in medical technology have made more resuscitations possible, and folk are able to report what happened when they were deid.Some described the usual stuff about a warm, welcoming light. Some raised the disturbing prospect of being greeted by deceased relatives. Some reported feeling scared. While others just hung about watching the doctors and nurses.I recall reading of episodes at the guillotine in revolutionary France where eyes on a newly detached bonce would carry on looking aboot and the mooth would say conversationally: ldquoI could fair murder a pint.Typically, the boffin under advisement is too feart to claim his findings mean therersquos an afterle but has come up with some outlandish bilge about the brain scanning itself as a survival technique.Irsquom convinced therersquos mair le, though, and accordingly am going to wear clean pants all time, instead of just Saturdays.
